member.name: T:Cadenza.DelegateRocks
member.summary: Provides extension methods on , , and related delegates.

remarks.para: provides methods methods for:
Currying via partial application is a way to easily transform functions which accept N arguments into functions which accept N-1 arguments, by "fixing" arguments with a value.

"Traditional" currying converts a delegate that accepts N arguments into a delegate which accepts only one argument, but when invoked may return a further delegate (etc.) until the final value is returned.
Composition is a way to easy chain (or pipe) together multiple delegates so that the return value of a "composer" delegate is used as the input parameter for the chained delegate:

member.typeparam: The return type, and argument type.
member.returns: Returns a which, when invoked, will invoke and pass the return value of to .

remarks.para: Composition is useful for chaining delegates together, so that the return value of is automatically used as the input parameter for .

remarks.para: This method calls , with as the type.

member.name: M:Cadenza.Either.TryParse``2(``0)
member.param: An instance of type containing the value to convert into a instance.
member.summary: Attempt to convert the value within a into an instance of type .
member.returns: A containing either the parsed value or the error that results from attempting to convert into an instance of type .

remarks.para: TryParse attempts to use a variety of mechanisms to convert into a , attempting, in order:
If none of these methods are able to convert the value, then the returned will contain a , and will contain the original exception.

An Either is an immutable, strongly typed union of variously typed values with each value lacking an otherwise meaningful name aside from its position, which is not exposed. It stores only one (non-null) value from a set of types (as determined by the type parameter list).

The value held by a instance can be converted into a value by using the method. Fold takes a list of delegates to perform the conversion; the delegate used to perform the conversion is based upon the internal position of the value stored.
Either instances are created through one of the following creation methods:
remarks.code: var a = Either<double, string>.A (Math.PI); // value stored in 1st position int r = a.Fold ( v => (int) v, // 1st position converter v => v.Length); // 2nd position converter Console.WriteLine (r); // prints 3

remarks.para: An Either is an immutable, strongly typed union of variously typed values with each value lacking an otherwise meaningful name aside from its position, which is not exposed. It stores only one (non-null) value from a set of types (as determined by the type parameter list).

The value held by a instance can be converted into a value by using the method. Fold takes a list of delegates to perform the conversion; the delegate used to perform the conversion is based upon the internal position of the value stored.
Either instances are created through one of the following creation methods:
remarks.code: var a = Either<double, string>.A (Math.PI); // value stored in 1st position int r = a.Fold ( v => (int) v, // 1st position converter v => v.Length); // 2nd position converter Console.WriteLine (r); // prints 3

member.name: T:Cadenza.Lambda
member.summary: Provides static utility methods to generate anonymous delegates or expression trees of pre-determined types.

remarks.para: C# lambda methods and anonymous delegates are a curious 1.5-class citizen: They are implicitly convertable to any delegate type, but have no type by themselves. Thus, the following code fails to compile:
remarks.code: ((int x) => Console.WriteLine (x))(5);
remarks.para: It would instead need:
So you'd either need to assign the lambda to an actual delegate type, or insert a cast.

member.name: T:Cadenza.Maybe`1
member.typeparam: The type of the optional value.
member.summary: Represents an optional value. An instance of can contain a value of type or an indication that the instance contains no value.

remarks.para: The value type represents a value of a given type or an indication that the instance contains no value. Such an optional value type is useful in a variety of situations, such as denoting that a conversion couldn't be performed without resorting to an exception or by-ref parameters ( or ).

An instance of has two properties, and . is used to determine whether the current instance currently has a value. It returns or , and never throws an exception. returns the current value of the instance, provided it has one (i.e., is ); otherwise, it throws an exception.

In addition to the above properties, there is a pair of methods, both overloads of . The version taking no arguments returns the instance's current value, if it has one; otherwise, it returns the default value of type . The version taking an argument of type returns the instance's current value, if it has one; otherwise, it returns the default value argument passed to it.
instances can be created in one of four ways:

item.term: By using the default constructor provided for all value types. This will create an instance that contains no value, and will be equal to .
By explicitly using the constructor. This will throw an if the value is .
By using the extension method. This will throw an if the value is .
By using the extension method. If the value is , then is returned.

member.name: T:Cadenza.NaturalStringComparer
member.summary:
Provides and
implementations to sort strings in a "natural" fashion.

remarks.para: "Natural" string comparison compares strings as humans would compare them, not as computers do. Thus the string "10" sorts after "2", whereas "normally" "10" would sort before "2" because normal string comparison works a character at a time, and "1" is before "2".

member.name: M:Cadenza.NaturalStringComparer.Compare(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the sort order of two instances.

returns.para: The return value is a negative number, zero, or a positive number reflecting the sort order of as compared to . For non-zero return values, the exact value returned by this method is unspecified. The following table defines the return value:
returns.block: A null reference is considered to compare less than any other non-null object, and equal to any other null reference, independent of the underlying of either object.

remarks.para: This method compares to using a "natural" string comparison algorithm, so that strings with embedded numeric data sort by the numeric data in conjunction with the surrounding string, instead of treating the numeric data as part of the string itself.

This allows "foo10" to sort after "foo2", as is usually expected when looking at sorted text, instead of having "foo10" sort before "foo2", as
would do.

remarks.para: This field is read-only.

member.name: F:Cadenza.Tuple.MaxValues
member.summary: The maximum number of Tuple types provided.

remarks.para: Only tuples up to a certain "arity" are supported; for example, a Tuple<T1, T2, ..., T100> isn't supported (and won't likely ever be).

is the maximum number of values that the Tuple types support. If you need to support more values, then you need to either live with potential boxing and use a e.g. or nest Tuple instantiations, e.g. Tuple<int, Tuple<int, Tuple<int, Tuple<int, int>>>>. The problem with such nesting is that it becomes "unnatural" to access later elements -- t._2._2._2._2 to access the fifth value for the previous example.

member.name: T:Cadenza.Tuple`1
member.summary: A strongly-typed sequence of 1 variously typed values.

remarks.para: A Tuple is an immutable, strongly typed sequence of variously typed values with each value lacking an otherwise meaningful name aside from its position.

Tuples provide an indexer to access variables by-index in a loosely typed manner, and provide a set of properties to access variables by-index in a strongly typed manner. Strongly typed properties use the pattern _N, where N is the ones-based value position. The indexer, as always, uses 0-based positions. Thus the value and tuple[0] refer to the same value, except is strongly typed, while tuple[0] is typed as a (and thus potentially boxed).
Tuples also implement the common collection interfaces, and all collection methods that would require mutating the Tuple throw .

member.name: T:Cadenza.Tuple`3
member.summary: A strongly-typed sequence of 3 variously typed values.

remarks.para: A Tuple is an immutable, strongly typed sequence of variously typed values with each value lacking an otherwise meaningful name aside from its position.

Tuples provide an indexer to access variables by-index in a loosely typed manner, and provide a set of properties to access variables by-index in a strongly typed manner. Strongly typed properties use the pattern _N, where N is the ones-based value position. The indexer, as always, uses 0-based positions. Thus the value and tuple[0] refer to the same value, except is strongly typed, while tuple[0] is typed as a (and thus potentially boxed).
Tuples also implement the common collection interfaces, and all collection methods that would require mutating the Tuple throw .
